key_points: The Senate unanimously approved posthumously awarding the Congressional Gold Medal to the 13 U.S. service members killed in a suicide bombing in Kabul in August.
The House had previously approved the medals, and the bill now awaits President Joe Biden's signature.
Sen. Steve Daines, R-Mont., and Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., introduced the bill with 67 co-sponsors.
The service members were killed in an Aug. 26 suicide bombing outside Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul.
The attack is criticized as part of a poorly planned evacuation, even as the Biden administration highlights the success of evacuating 124,000 people.
An estimated 170 Afghans were also killed in the suicide blast.
The Pentagon identified the service members killed, including 11 Marines, one Navy corpsman, and one Army staff sergeant.
The bill states that the service members went 'above and beyond the call of duty' during the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan.
The Congressional Gold Medal is one of the highest civilian awards in the United States.
"The American service members dedicated their lives and their heroism deserves great honor," says the bill.
